questions.text: Four days after undergoing a total abdominal hysterectomy for atypical endometrial hyperplasia, a 59-year-old woman reports abdominal bloating and discomfort. She has also had nausea without vomiting. She has no appetite despite not having eaten since the surgery and drinking only sips of water. Her postoperative pain has been well controlled on a hydromorphone patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) pump. Her indwelling urinary catheter was removed on the second postoperative day and she is now voiding freely. Although she lies supine in bed for most of the day, she is able to walk around the hospital room with the help of a physical therapist. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 132/92 mm Hg. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 115 kg (253 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Examination shows a mildly distended, tympanic abdomen; bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An x-ray of the abdomen shows uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Return to operating room for bowel resection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gastrografin enema can be used to differentiate between partial and complete mechanical bowel obstruction or to evacuate stool from the rectum and colon in patients with large bowel obstruction. This patient has a functional bowel obstruction that affects the smooth muscle of both her small and large intestine. While a gastrografin enema may help to temporarily relieve constipation in her colon, it would not resolve the intestinal paralysis; therefore, gastrografin enema does not routinely play a role in the management of postoperative paralytic ileus.

B) INCORRECT:

Although not routinely performed in the workup of bowel obstruction, esophagogastroduodenoscopy could help to detect an underlying mechanical cause of the obstruction within the upper GI tract (e.g., a malignant tumor, stricture, or foreign body); however, abdominal x-ray and/or CT scan are generally preferred. Since this patient has a functional bowel obstruction, which results from temporary intestinal paralysis, upper endoscopy would not be indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Postoperative ileus is one of the most common causes of paralytic ileus. Intraabdominal surgery itself results in inflammation of the intestinal wall, impairing coordinated propulsive peristalsis of the intestinal smooth muscle. Opioids, such as the hydromorphone that was used for analgesia in this patient, also have an inhibitory effect on peristalsis, which has likely contributed to the development of paralytic ileus. Treatment consists mainly of supportive measures (i.e., bowel rest, using a nasogastric tube for intestinal decompression, fluid resuscitation, and electrolyte correction). Drugs that might sustain or prolong paralytic ileus (e.g., anticholinergics, opioids) should be reduced or discontinued, if possible, while NSAIDs or acetaminophen should be administered for pain control.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a patient with COVID-19, acute renal failure, and paralytic ileus

Gaseous distention of both small and large bowel is the result of paralytic ileus.

C: cecum; SB: small bowel; SF: splenic flexure; TC: transverse colon

D) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy may be considered in patients with large bowel obstruction to evacuate stool from the rectum and colon. However, this patient has a functional bowel obstruction that affects the smooth muscle of both her small and her large intestine. Colonoscopic bowel decompression does not resolve the intestinal paralysis and is not part of the management of postoperative paralytic ileus.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with complete mechanical bowel obstruction, persistent partial obstruction, and/or signs of bowel ischemia should be taken to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy to identify and remove the underlying cause of obstruction. Mechanical bowel obstruction may also present with abdominal distention, discomfort, and nausea, as seen in this patient; however, auscultation usually reveals increased high-pitched sounds and abdominal x-ray demonstrates distended loops of small or large bowel, air-fluid levels proximal to the obstruction, and collapse of the distal bowel.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view; erect position)

Multiple air-fluid levels (green overlay) are visible in the mid-abdomen. The opaque appearance of the pelvis (red overlay) is due to fluid-filled loops of small bowel. There is a paucity of gas in the colon, and an air-fluid level is present in the dilated stomach (S).

Erect and decubitus radiographs can reveal air-fluid levels that are not identifiable on supine radiographs. Air-fluid levels can indicate ileus or mechanical obstruction. A lack of distal gas and air-fluid levels at different heights in the same bowel loop (differential air-fluid levels) suggest obstruction.

F) INCORRECT:

Total parenteral nutrition can be indicated in critically ill patients or patients who cannot tolerate oral intake for a prolonged period of time. While this patient with paralytic ileus should avoid oral intake until her bowel function has normalized, parenteral nutrition is not indicated at this time.

G) INCORRECT:

Increased oral intake would further compress the functionally obstructed bowel and should thus be avoided in this patient. Instead, she should remain on bowel rest until her postoperative paralytic ileus has resolved. Sips of clear fluids are permitted if tolerated.
questions.hint: This patient who has just had major abdominal surgery now has hypomobility of the gastrointestinal tract for more than three days after surgery. Her clinical picture (distended, tympanitic abdomen, absent bowel sounds) and imaging findings (uniform distribution of gas) suggest paralytic ileus.

questions.text: Four days after having been admitted to the hospital for a pulmonary contusion and whiplash injury sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a 66-year-old woman complains of severe pain in her right flank, abdominal bloating, and nausea. She has also vomited twice in the past 2 hours. Her musculoskeletal pain due to the motor vehicle collision had been well controlled with acetaminophen every 6 hours but the medication provides no relief for the flank pain. She underwent umbilical hernia repair surgery 2 years ago. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 102/72 mm Hg. After administration of 0.5 L of crystalloid fluids, blood pressure improves to 118/79 mm Hg. Multiple ecchymoses are present over the anterior abdominal wall in a pattern that follows the course of a seatbelt and there are new ecchymoses over the flanks bilaterally. Bowel sounds are absent. There is tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding. Her hemoglobin is 7.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8500/mm3, platelet count is 350,000/mm3, prothrombin time is 11 seconds, and activated partial thromboplastin time is 33 seconds. An x-ray of the abdomen shows obliteration of the right psoas shadow, dilated bowel loops, and uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small bowel perforation causes acute abdominal pain and may be associated with paralytic ileus. However, small bowel perforation would cause free intraperitoneal air on abdominal x-ray (70% of cases) and it does not explain unilateral obliteration of the psoas muscle shadow, flank pain, or flank bruising.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP erect view) and chest (PA and lateral views)

Multiple air-fluid levels are seen in the colon and small bowel (examples indicated by black lines). Some dilated segments of left colon are seen and gas is present in the peritoneal space as a result of bowel perforation. Gas is primarily located beneath the diaphragms (green overlay) because of the erect positioning of the patient. Additional gas has dissected into the retroperitoneum (examples indicated by red overlay) and is visible as linear collections parallel to the spine.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraabdominal adhesions are a common cause of mechanical bowel obstruction, especially in patients with a history of intraperitoneal surgery. Mechanical bowel obstruction manifests with acute obstructive symptoms (bloating, nausea, vomiting) as in this patient, but hyperactive bowel sounds and air-fluid levels (possibly with a transition point) on x-ray would be expected in mechanical obstruction.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view; erect position)

Multiple air-fluid levels (green overlay) are visible in the mid-abdomen. The opaque appearance of the pelvis (red overlay) is due to fluid-filled loops of small bowel. There is a paucity of gas in the colon, and an air-fluid level is present in the dilated stomach (S).

Erect and decubitus radiographs can reveal air-fluid levels that are not identifiable on supine radiographs. Air-fluid levels can indicate ileus or mechanical obstruction. A lack of distal gas and air-fluid levels at different heights in the same bowel loop (differential air-fluid levels) suggest obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Pain medications (especially opioids) can cause paralytic ileus. Opioids bind the μ receptor in the gut, which directly inhibits gut motility. However, this patient's pain was controlled with acetaminophen only, which does not cause paralytic ileus.

D) INCORRECT:

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of mechanical bowel obstruction, particularly in older patients such as this one. Mechanical bowel obstruction presents with acute obstructive symptoms (bloating, nausea, vomiting) as in this patient, but hyperactive bowel sounds and air-fluid levels (possibly with a transition point) would be expected in mechanical obstruction. Sigmoid volvulus also has coffee bean sign on x-ray in 60% of patients.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (left lateral decubitus view)

Gaseous distention of a closed loop of sigmoid colon (red overlay) has caused apposition of the medial walls (green lines). The resultant cleft-like configuration, in conjunction with the lateral walls of the loop, produces an appearance reminiscent of a coffee bean (illustration).

The coffee bean sign (also called “kidney-bean sign” or “bent-inner-tube sign”) is a classic conventional radiographic finding of sigmoid volvulus.

Dashed line: air-fluid level

E) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord injury can cause paralytic ileus. This patient suffered whiplash injury from her accident, which can be associated with mild neurologic injury and signs such as numbness and weakness. However, neurologic injury from whiplash is not significant enough to cause ileus and this patient has had no other evidence of severe neurologic injury (e.g., significant weakness). Significant spinal cord damage is, therefore, unlikely.

F) CORRECT:

Trauma patients may develop paralytic ileus for a variety of reasons (e.g., treatment with opioids). The association of this patient's ileus with bilateral flank pain, seatbelt sign, Grey Turner sign, obliteration of the psoas outline on x-ray, and fluid-responsive hemodynamic changes make trauma-associated retroperitoneal hemorrhage the most likely cause of symptoms here.

The most appropriate next step in the management of uncomplicated paralytic ileus is to make the patient NPO, place a nasogastric tube for decompression, and provide IV fluid (and possibly blood product) resuscitation. Hemodynamic status must also be monitored closely for signs of ongoing or recurrent retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

G) INCORRECT:

Acute mesenteric ischemia frequently presents as acute abdominal pain, distention, nausea, and vomiting. Acute mesenteric ischemia can occur as a complication of abdominal trauma and can cause paralytic ileus. However, acute mesenteric ischemia does not cause flank pain or flank bruising.
questions.hint: The presence of acute nausea, vomiting, bloating, absent bowel sounds, and dilated bowel loops with a uniform gas pattern is diagnostic of paralytic ileus.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man is on postoperative day 3 after a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer. He presents with bloating and mild nausea. He has had minimal bowel sounds and has not passed flatus since surgery. He is tolerating oral intake poorly and remains on intravenous fluids (see report).
Abdominal radiograph: Dilated loops of small and large bowel without air-fluid levels
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain immediate CT scan of the abdomen
Obtain serum chemistry panel and correct abnormalities

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide enhances gastric emptying and proximal gastrointestinal motility but has limited effect on colonic motility. This patient's diffuse motility dysfunction, indicated by dilated bowel loops without air-fluid levels, aligns with postoperative ileus, not effectively addressed by metoclopramide.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scans are indicated for severe pain, peritonitis, or infection signs. This patient, on postoperative day 3, has symptoms and imaging findings consistent with ileus, not warranting immediate CT imaging without red flag signs.

C) CORRECT:

Postoperative ileus manifests with transient bowel motility impairment after abdominal surgery, often exacerbated by electrolyte imbalances like hypokalemia. This patient presents with minimal bowel sounds, absence of flatus, and bowel dilation on imaging without air-fluid levels, indicating ileus rather than mechanical obstruction. A serum chemistry panel helps identify and correct electrolyte disturbances, crucial for restoring intestinal contractility and resolving ileus. Postoperative ileus is typically self-limiting, managed conservatively by addressing modifiable factors and allowing time for recovery.

Key learning point: In the management of postoperative ileus, checking and correcting serum electrolyte imbalances is a crucial step, as electrolyte disturbances can contribute to impaired bowel motility.

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical exploration is reserved for severe complications like peritonitis or hemodynamic instability. This patient, on postoperative day 3, presents with mild symptoms and imaging findings consistent with ileus, not mechanical obstruction or other emergencies requiring surgery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 4 days after exploratory laparotomy for small bowel obstruction. She reports nausea, vomiting, and continuous abdominal discomfort. She has not passed gas or stool for 2 days. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal distention with absent bowel sounds and no focal tenderness. Laboratory studies show normal lactate and mild hypokalemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent colonoscopy to rule out mechanical obstruction
Nasogastric tube insertion and IV fluid resuscitation
CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Immediate surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy
Nasogastric tube insertion and serial lactate monitoring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not indicated in the acute management of suspected paralytic ileus. This patient's clinical presentation and timing after recent surgery strongly suggest postoperative ileus, which requires conservative management rather than endoscopic evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic findings of postoperative paralytic ileus occurring within the expected timeframe after abdominal surgery. Initial management includes bowel rest, IV fluid resuscitation, and symptom relief. Nasogastric tube insertion is appropriate for symptomatic relief of distention and vomiting.

C) INCORRECT:

While CT imaging may be considered to rule out mechanical obstruction, this patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with postoperative paralytic ileus. Normal vital signs, normal lactate, and typical timing make conservative management the initial approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy is not indicated in this stable patient with likely postoperative paralytic ileus. Surgery is only indicated for underlying causes requiring intervention or complications, such as ischemia or perforation.

E) INCORRECT:

While nasogastric tube insertion is appropriate, serial lactate monitoring is not specifically indicated in stable paralytic ileus. Lactate elevation suggests ischemia or sepsis, which are rare complications and not supported by this patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distention following repair of an incarcerated umbilical hernia. She has not passed flatus or had a bowel movement since the procedure. Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal distention with tympany and absent bowel sounds. There is no peritoneal irritation. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 88; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). CT scan shows diffuse small and large bowel dilatation without a transition point. Laboratory studies show potassium 2.6 mEq/L, magnesium 1.4 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.3 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate priority in management?

choices.text: Parenteral nutrition and extended bowel rest
Immediate surgical consultation for bowel obstruction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laxatives should not be used until mechanical bowel obstruction has been definitively ruled out. While early mobilization may be beneficial, it does not address the immediate fluid and electrolyte abnormalities that require correction.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- In paralytic ileus, the priority is supportive care with IV fluid resuscitation and correction of electrolyte abnormalities, particularly hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, which can perpetuate the ileus. This patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest dehydration requiring fluid therapy, while the severe electrolyte disturbances must be corrected, as they are contributing factors to the ileus.

C) INCORRECT:

Parenteral nutrition is only considered if ileus persists for 7 days or more. The priority in acute management is addressing the underlying metabolic abnormalities and dehydration that may be perpetuating the ileus.

D) INCORRECT:

The CT findings of diffuse bowel dilatation without a transition point are characteristic of paralytic ileus rather than mechanical obstruction. The absence of peritoneal signs and the postoperative timing make this a functional rather than mechanical problem, requiring conservative management initially.

E) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric decompression is not routinely indicated for paralytic ileus and should only be considered for symptomatic relief of significant distention or refractory vomiting. Prokinetic agents are not first-line treatment and should only be considered after mechanical obstruction has been definitively ruled out.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is on postoperative day 3 following an exploratory laparotomy for a small bowel obstruction. He reports increasing abdominal distention and nausea but denies vomiting. He has not passed flatus or had a bowel movement since surgery. His temperature is 37.5°C, heart rate is 95/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. An abdominal radiograph shows diffusely dilated loops of both small and large bowel. He is currently receiving intravenous lactated Ringer's and patient-controlled analgesia with hydromorphone. Which of the following is the most appropriate adjustment to the patient's current management?

choices.text: Transition to a multimodal, opioid-sparing analgesic regimen
Order an urgent computed tomography scan of the abdomen
Insert a nasogastric tube for decompression

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has a classic presentation of postoperative ileus, a functional inhibition of gastrointestinal motility. The radiograph showing diffuse dilation of both small and large bowel confirms this diagnosis. A primary contributor to prolonged ileus is the use of opioids, like hydromorphone, which decrease peristalsis. The most appropriate adjustment is to address this underlying cause by transitioning to multimodal analgesia. This strategy combines non-opioid medications such as NSAIDs, acetaminophen, and gabapentinoids to provide adequate pain control while minimizing or eliminating the need for opioids. Reducing the opioid burden is a critical step to facilitate the return of normal bowel function and is a core principle of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery protocols.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan would be indicated if there were concern for a postoperative complication such as a recurrent mechanical obstruction, anastomotic leak, or intra-abdominal abscess. However, this patient's afebrile status and the radiographic finding of diffuse dilation involving both small and large bowel are highly characteristic of a postoperative paralytic ileus, making further imaging unnecessary at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Early ambulation is an important standard component of postoperative care that helps prevent and resolve ileus. While this should be encouraged, it is part of routine management rather than a specific adjustment to address this patient's worsening condition. The most impactful intervention is to modify the primary factor that is actively perpetuating the ileus.

D) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube placement is a supportive measure for managing severe symptoms of ileus, particularly in patients with significant vomiting or massive distention causing respiratory compromise. While it can relieve symptoms, this patient is not currently vomiting. Placing a nasogastric tube does not address the underlying cause of the prolonged ileus and is not the most fundamental adjustment to make at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that can stimulate gastrointestinal motility. However, its use in established postoperative ileus is controversial, with limited evidence of benefit. Furthermore, stimulating bowel contractility is potentially harmful if a mechanical obstruction has not been definitively ruled out.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical picture and radiographic findings point to a postoperative paralytic ileus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is on postoperative day 4 following a laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis. He reports increasing nausea, abdominal bloating, and has had one episode of bilious emesis. He has not passed flatus since the surgery. His diet was advanced to clear liquids this morning, which he could not tolerate. He is receiving IV IV hydromorphone via a patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) pump. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended, tympanitic abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds. There is no rebound or guarding. An abdominal x-ray shows diffusely dilated loops of small and large bowel. Which of the following is the most appropriate change in this patient's management?

choices.text: Make the patient nil per os and place a nasogastric tube
Arrange for an emergency exploratory laparotomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that increases gastrointestinal motility. While this seems logical for an ileus, prokinetics are generally contraindicated in a bowel obstruction, even a functional one. Stimulating motility in an obstructed bowel can worsen abdominal cramping and pain without resolving the underlying issue. Its use in postoperative ileus is not a first-line therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Key features of postoperative ileus include nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and failure to pass flatus after abdominal surgery. The x-ray showing diffuse dilation of both small and large bowel confirms the diagnosis. The most appropriate initial management is supportive care, which includes bowel rest (nil per os status) and gastric decompression with a nasogastric tube. This relieves symptoms of nausea and vomiting, reduces distention, and prevents complications like aspiration. IV fluids should also be administered to maintain hydration and correct any electrolyte abnormalities.

C) INCORRECT:

An emergency laparotomy would be indicated for a mechanical bowel obstruction or a postoperative complication like an anastomotic leak with peritonitis. While this patient has signs of obstruction, the diffuse dilation of both small and large bowel on imaging and the absence of peritoneal signs (rebound, guarding) or high fever make a functional ileus far more likely. Surgery is not indicated for an uncomplicated postoperative ileus.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrolyte abnormalities, particularly hypokalemia, can cause or prolong a postoperative ileus. While correcting electrolytes is a component of supportive care, there is no evidence that this patient is hypokalemic. Furthermore, administering potassium would not address the immediate symptoms of distention and vomiting.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation and radiographic finding of diffusely dilated bowel four days after major abdominal surgery are classic for postoperative ileus.
